els.title: Gulf Stream
els.text: This fast-moving current carries heat from the tropics toward the poles along the coast of North America.

els.title: Kuroshio Current
els.text: A warm current running north from the tropics. In the mid-latitudes, it joins the North Pacific current and flows eastward.

els.title: Hadley cells
els.text: Warm air rises from the equator, then cools as it moves toward the poles. This cool air sinks to the surface, creating a loop of air circulation known as a Hadley cell.

els.title: Peru Current
els.text: A cold, north-flowing current that brings nutrients to sea life near South America. This current weakens during El Niño years, warming coastal areas and reducing fish populations.

els.title: Southern Ocean
els.text: The world’s largest current circles Antarctica. Here, very cold, nutrient-rich bottom waters rise to the surface, travel north and are distributed throughout the world’s oceans.

els.title: Northern Polar Front
els.text: Here, cold polar air meets warm air moving north from equator. This forms a fast-flowing, wavy river of air that drives weather patterns from west to east.

els.title: Trade Winds
els.text: Some warm, tropical air cools and sinks before reaching the poles. These masses return to the equator, flowing southeast in the Northern Hemisphere and northwest in the Southern Hemisphere. They meet at the Intertropical Convergence Zone.

els.title: Coriolis Effect
els.text: Earth’s rotation deflects rising air masses. Without this force, air would move directly from the tropics to the poles—but the Coriolis Effect results in currents moving in a curved path.
